commit_message:
Rework scheduling filters

Remove ValidationFilter, make it a part of reservation to avoid calling
it too many times. Fix AttributeError on failing the custom predicate.
Remove double validation in the reserver, we do another validation later
on anyway.

BREAKING: changes the exception classes.

Change-Id: Ibc3815989917ab777298a05810fd8f3e64debc8f
Story: #2003584
Task: #26178
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/metalsmith refs/changes/64/600764/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class NodeTypeFilter(Filter): """Filter that checks resource class and conductor group.""" def __init__(self, resource_class=None, conductor_group=None): self.resource_class = resource_class self.conductor_group = conductor_group def __call__(self, node): return ( (self.resource_class is None or node.resource_class == self.resource_class) and (self.conductor_group is None or node.conductor_group == self.conductor_group) ) def fail(self): raise exceptions.NodesNotFound(self.resource_class, self.conductor_group) class CustomPredicateFilter(Filter): def __init__(self, predicate): self.predicate = predicate if not self.predicate(node): message = 'No nodes satisfied the custom predicate %s' % self.predicate raise exceptions.CustomPredicateFailed(message, self._failed_nodes) def validate(self, node): try: self._api.validate_node(node) except RuntimeError as exc: message = ('Node %(node)s failed validation: %(err)s' % {'node': _utils.log_node(node), 'err': exc}) LOG.warning(message) raise exceptions.ValidationFailed(message) self.validate(node) return self._api.reserve_node(node, instance_uuid=node.uuid) raise exceptions.NoNodesReserved(self._failed_nodes)
deleted_lines: class ValidationFilter(Filter): """Filter that runs validation on nodes.""" def __init__(self, api): self._api = api self._messages = [] try: self._api.validate_node(node.uuid) except RuntimeError as exc: message = ('Node %(node)s failed validation: %(err)s' % {'node': _utils.log_node(node), 'err': exc}) LOG.warning(message) self._messages.append(message) errors = ", ".join(self._messages) message = "All available nodes have failed validation: %s" % errors raise exceptions.ValidationFailed(message, self._failed_nodes) result = self._api.reserve_node(node, instance_uuid=node.uuid) # Try validation again to be sure nothing has changed validator = ValidationFilter(self._api) if not validator(result): LOG.warning('Validation of node %s failed after reservation', _utils.log_node(node)) try: self._api.release_node(node) except Exception: LOG.exception('Failed to release the reserved node %s', _utils.log_node(node)) validator.fail() return result raise exceptions.AllNodesReserved(self._failed_nodes)

commit_message:
Gate: Move dev-deploy jobs to nonvoting temporarily

This changes the dev-deploy-ceph and dev-deploy-nfs jobs to
nonvoting jobs, until we can revisit the services being deployed
as part of these jobs. Currently, these jobs are pushing the
limits of a single nodepool VM which results in random failures in
the jobs themselves or the postrun jobs.

Change-Id: I9a6e68dc472b81b9c13b95520f4bef4cdb091beb

added_lines: %global sname networking-generic-switch Name: {{ py2name('networking-generic-switch') }} Version: 1.1.0 Release: 0 Summary: Generic Switch ML2 Neutron Driver License: {{ license('Apache-2.0') }} Group: Development/Languages/Python URL: https://launchpad.net/%{sname} Source0: https://files.pythonhosted.org/packages/source/k/%{sname}/%{sname}-%{version}.tar.gz BuildRequires: openstack-macros BuildRequires: {{ py2pkg('stevedore') }} BuildRequires: {{ py2pkg('netmiko') }} BuildRequires: {{ py2pkg('neutron') }} BuildRequires: {{ py2pkg('neutron-lib') }} BuildRequires: {{ py2pkg('oslo.config') }} BuildRequires: {{ py2pkg('oslo.db') }} BuildRequires: {{ py2pkg('oslo.i18n') }} BuildRequires: {{ py2pkg('oslo.log') }} BuildRequires: {{ py2pkg('oslo.middleware') }} BuildRequires: {{ py2pkg('oslosphinx') }} BuildRequires: {{ py2pkg('oslotest') }} BuildRequires: {{ py2pkg('six') }} BuildRequires: {{ py2pkg('tenacity') }} BuildRequires: {{ py2pkg('tooz') }} BuildRequires: {{ py2pkg('testrepository') }} BuildRequires: {{ py2pkg('testresources') }} BuildRequires: {{ py2pkg('testtools') }} Requires: {{ py2pkg('stevedore') }} Requires: {{ py2pkg('netmiko') }} Requires: {{ py2pkg('neutron') }} Requires: {{ py2pkg('oslo.config') }} Requires: {{ py2pkg('oslo.db') }} Requires: {{ py2pkg('oslo.i18n') }} Requires: {{ py2pkg('oslo.log') }} Requires: {{ py2pkg('oslo.middleware') }} Requires: {{ py2pkg('six') }} Requires: {{ py2pkg('tenacity') }} Requires: {{ py2pkg('tooz') }} BuildArch: noarch %description This is a Modular Layer 2 `Neutron Mechanism driver <https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Neutron/ML2>`_. The mechanism driver is responsible for applying configuration information to hardware equipment. ``GenericSwitch`` provides a pluggable framework to implement functionality required for use-cases like OpenStack Ironic multi-tenancy mode. It abstracts applying changes to all switches managed by this ML2 plugin and handling ``local_link_information`` field of Neutron port. %package doc Summary: Generic Switch ML2 Neutron Driver Doc Group: Documentation/HTML BuildRequires: {{ py2pkg('Sphinx') }} BuildRequires: {{ py2pkg('openstackdocstheme') }} BuildRequires: {{ py2pkg('reno') }} %description doc Documentation for OpenStack Generic Switch ML2 Neutron Driver. %prep %autosetup -n networking-generic-switch-%{version} %py_req_cleanup sed -i 's/^warning-is-error.*/warning-is-error = 0/g' setup.cfg %build %{py2_build} # Build HTML docs and man page %{__python2} setup.py build_sphinx # remove the sphinx-build leftovers rm -rf doc/build/html/.{doctrees,buildinfo} %install %{py2_install} %check %{__python2} setup.py testr %files %license LICENSE %doc README.rst %{python2_sitelib}/networking_generic_switch %{python2_sitelib}/networking_generic_switch*egg-info %files doc %license LICENSE %doc doc/build/html %changelog

commit_message:
Remove tox_install.sh

As part of removing reliance on the old and deprecated zuul-cloner, we
need to shift constraints declaration to the deps line. This means we
unfortunately have to duplicate the extras declarations into
test-requirements - because otherwise the contraints for
keystonemiddleware conflicts with the installation of itself.

Conflicts:
 Updated tox.ini to pull stable/queens constraints

Change-Id: I8dbb31d1c1fda6df386f456dcf1d8bbed6d168ce
(cherry picked from commit 4f6c28c1c1da19fca821f5abe1008cb89289947f)

the integration gate fails because ceilometer isn't on pypi[1].  There
aren't any good fixes but this *should* at least unblock the,
requirements, gate and buy us time to fix it correctly.

Note:

commit_message:
Remove networking-odl from g-r in the requirements-integration job

This is a terrible idea!

Since networking-odl 13.0.0 hit pypi which includes I955c9d737864b8a2557366be518922e192f4be91
the integration gate fails because ceilometer isn't on pypi[1].  There
aren't any good fixes but this *should* at least unblock the,
requirements, gate and buy us time to fix it correctly.

Note:
 * We can't just install ceilometer from git as we'll just fail when we
   try to generate a constraints list anyway.
 * We can't blacklist networking-odl as the backlist isn't used for
   generating a freeze only for filtering the output constraints
 * We can't stop building the constratints as that introduces a new
   failure path in the gate.

So with those options ruled out lets just pretend that networking-odl
isn't in global-requirements.  This will still fail if something
(directly or not) installs it from pypi.

[1] http://logs.openstack.org/96/594496/2/check/requirements-integration/8378cd8/job-output.txt.gz#_2018-08-31_22_54_49_357505

Change-Id: I1f117f9f4d8f49b5c4ef0cb74d98560c9a551999
(cherry picked from commit 3fe4d09d8ffbf254891924d01906e3486b4b9347)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/requirements refs/changes/23/600523/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if grep -q ^networking-odl $REPODIR/requirements/global-requirements.txt ; then cat <<EO_FIGLET _ _ _ ____ _ __ _ | | | | / \ / ___|| |/ /| | | |_| | / _ \ | | | ' / | | | _ | / ___ \| |___ | . \ |_| |_| |_|/_/ \_\\____||_|\_\(_) EO_FIGLET sed -i~ -e '/^networking-odl/d' $REPODIR/requirements/global-requirements.txt diff -U0 $REPODIR/requirements/global-requirements.txt{~,} || true fi

commit_message:
Shift to check_policy for resource creation

This change removes the protected decorator from both project and user
create APIs and replaces it with both assert_authentication and
check_protection, which calls check_policy.

This allows for user/project creation data from the request body to be
passed into check_policy in a way that can be checked against. With
the protected decorator, this data gets passed in through args, but
is never used. This data can then be referenced against various
policy rules.

This change modifies a test to expect a 201 Created instead of a 403
Forbidden. The reason a 403 was previously acceptable is because the
oslo.policy library never rendered a `result` when `domain-id` was
passed to `ENFORCER.enforce()`. Now that the request is being
normalized before policy inforcement, `domain-id` is translated to
`domain_id`, which oslo.policy handles and returns a `result` for.

Change-Id: I7f17fb6497de40f194f227f1de7a551a18ae6ce7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/70/462670/22 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from keystone.common import authorization def create_project(self, request, project): request.assert_authenticated() try: domain_id = project['domain_id'] except KeyError: domain_id = request.context.domain_id if domain_id is None: domain_id = CONF.identity.default_domain_id project['domain_id'] = domain_id kwargs = {'project': ref} args = [self, request, ref] authorization.check_policy( self, request, 'create_project', filter_attr=None, input_attr=kwargs, target_attr=None, args=args, kwargs=kwargs)

commit_message:
Region Support

WIP for spec that will describe the "stretch galera cluster"
approach which builds a shared Galera cluster among multiple
overclouds.

Change-Id: I26b9d7ba6bf4f8ca1495774db0b2afc51e04693c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-specs refs/changes/48/566448/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ======================= Multiple Region Support ======================= Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/tripleo/regions Support deploying a second and addtional regions to external overclouds Problem Description =================== OpenStack has supported Regions since before Tripleo existed. However, Tripleo has thus far restricted itself to a single region. Proposed Change =============== Overview -------- 1. Add a new undercloud to the existing overcloud. `openstack undercloud add --config <file>` 2. Add a region on the new undercloud `openstack overcloud extend <undercloud> <region` A. Create a new region in the existing OverCLoud Keystone B. Create a new database server on the new undercloud C. Replicate the existing Keystone Database to the new undercloud. 3. Add new servers to the region. Each of these command can be performed separately. A. Add a Nova stack. This is all Nova componentes, including API server, scheduler, etc/ B. Add a Glance Server C. Add a Cinder Server D. Add a Neutron server Alternatives ------------ Spin uip multiple Overcloud and use Keystone-to-Keystone (K2K) Federation is the only existing option today. Security Impact --------------- A full security Audit of the code is required. Biggest risks come from extending to an insecure undercloud. Communication between the regions must be secured, especially for the Database replication Other End User Impact --------------------- Only Operators will do this. Performance Impact ------------------ Keystone Database replication must be tuned. It has the potential to impact token validations, which is the "Hot" path. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- The biggest change will be that the overcloud now will work with multiple underclouds. The Deployer will need to be able to maintain all of them. Upgrades will likely be done one Undercloud at a time, which can be quite tricky. Developer Impact ---------------- Discuss things that will affect other developers working on OpenStack. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Who is leading the writing of the code? Or is this a blueprint where you're throwing it out there to see who picks it up? If more than one person is working on the implementation, please designate the primary author and contact. Primary assignee: <launchpad-id or None> Other contributors: <launchpad-id or None> Work Items ---------- Work items or tasks -- break the feature up into the things that need to be done to implement it. Those parts might end up being done by different people, but we're mostly trying to understand the timeline for implementation. Dependencies ============ * Include specific references to specs and/or blueprints in tripleo, or in other projects, that this one either depends on or is related to. * If this requires functionality of another project that is not currently used by Tripleo (such as the glance v2 API when we previously only required v1), document that fact. * Does this feature require any new library dependencies or code otherwise not included in OpenStack? Or does it depend on a specific version of library? Testing ======= Please discuss how the change will be tested. Is this untestable in CI given current limitations (specific hardware / software configurations available)? If so, are there mitigation plans (3rd party testing, gate enhancements, etc). Documentation Impact ==================== What is the impact on the docs? Don't repeat details discussed above, but please reference them here. References ========== Please add any useful references here. You are not required to have any reference. Moreover, this specification should still make sense when your references are unavailable. Examples of what you could include are: * Links to mailing list or IRC discussions * Links to notes from a summit session * Links to relevant research, if appropriate * Related specifications as appropriate (e.g. if it's an EC2 thing, link the EC2 docs) * Anything else you feel it is worthwhile to refer to

added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Example Spec - The title of your blueprint ========================================== `bp example <https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/example>`_ Introduction paragraph -- why are we doing anything? A single paragraph of prose that operators can understand. Some notes about using this template: * Your spec should be in `ReSTructured text <http://sphinx-doc.org/rest.html>`_, like this template. * Wrap text at 79 columns. * The filename in the git repository should match the launchpad URL, for example a URL of: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/new-feature should be named new-feature.rst * Do not delete any of the sections in this template. If you have nothing to say for a whole section, just write: None * To test out your formatting, build the docs using tox, or see: http://rst.ninjs.org * If you would like to provide a diagram with your spec, ascii diagrams are required. http://asciiflow.com/ is a very nice tool to assist with making ascii diagrams. The reason for this is that the tool used to review specs is based purely on plain text. Plain text will allow review to proceed without having to look at additional files which can not be viewed in gerrit. It will also allow inline feedback on the diagram itself. * If your spec has an impact on the HTTP API, propose the corresponding changes to the ``api/`` directory for review along with your spec and add the APIImpact flag to the commit message. Specifications with the APIImpact flag can be found with this query_. .. _query: https://review.openstack.org/#/q/status:open+project:openstack/keystone-specs+message:apiimpact,n,z Problem Description =================== A detailed description of the problem: * For a new feature, this might be use cases. Ensure you are clear about the actors in each use case: End User vs Deployer * For a major reworking of part of the code, it would describe the problems in that feature that are being addressed. This section should clearly communicate *why* it is desirable for the community to have a solution to the issue. Proposed Change =============== Here is where you describe the change you propose to make. How do you propose to solve this problem? Address the issue at an architectural level, leaving the implementation details for code review. If this is one part of a larger effort make it clear where this piece ends. In other words, what's the scope of this effort? Alternatives ------------ What other ways could we do this thing? Why aren't we using those? This doesn't have to be a full literature review, but it should demonstrate that thought has been put into why the proposed solution is an appropriate one. Security Impact --------------- Describe any potential security impact on the system. Some of the items to consider include: * Does this change touch sensitive data such as tokens, keys, or user data? * Does this change alter the API in a way that may impact security, such as a new way to access sensitive information or a new way to login? * Does this change involve cryptography or hashing? * Does this change require the use of sudo or any elevated privileges? * Does this change involve using or parsing user-provided data? This could be directly at the API level or indirectly such as changes to a cache layer. * Can this change enable a resource exhaustion attack, such as allowing a single API interaction to consume significant server resources? Some examples of this include launching subprocesses for each connection, or entity expansion attacks in XML. For more detailed guidance, please see the OpenStack Security Guidelines as a reference (https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Security/Guidelines). These guidelines are a work in progress and are designed to help you identify security best practices. For further information, feel free to reach out to the OpenStack Security Group at openstack-security@lists.openstack.org. Notifications Impact -------------------- Please specify any changes to notifications. Be that an extra notification, changes to an existing notification, or removing a notification. Other End User Impact --------------------- Aside from the API, are there other ways a user will interact with this feature? * Does this change have an impact on python-keystoneclient? What does the user interface there look like? Performance Impact ------------------ Describe any potential performance impact on the system, for example how often will new code be called, and is there a major change to the calling pattern of existing code. Examples of things to consider here include: * A small change in a utility function or a commonly used decorator can have a large impacts on performance. * Calls which result in a database queries can have a profound impact on performance when called in critical sections of the code. * Will the change include any locking, and if so what considerations are there on holding the lock? Other Deployer Impact --------------------- Discuss things that will affect how you deploy and configure OpenStack that have not already been mentioned, such as: * What config options are being added? Should they be more generic than proposed (for example a flag that other hypervisor drivers might want to implement as well)? Are the default values ones which will work well in real deployments? * Is this a change that takes immediate effect after its merged, or is it something that has to be explicitly enabled? * If this change is a new binary, how would it be deployed? * Please state anything that those doing continuous deployment, or those upgrading from the previous release, need to be aware of. Also describe any plans to deprecate configuration values or features. For example, if we change the directory name that instances are stored in, how do we handle instance directories created before the change landed? Do we move them? Do we have a special case in the code? Do we assume that the operator will recreate all the instances in their cloud? Developer Impact ---------------- Discuss things that will affect other developers working on OpenStack, such as: * If the blueprint proposes a change to the driver API, discussion of how other backends would implement the feature is required. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Who is leading the writing of the code? Or is this a blueprint where you're throwing it out there to see who picks it up? If more than one person is working on the implementation, please designate the primary author and contact. Primary assignee: <launchpad-id or None> Other contributors: <launchpad-id or None> Work Items ---------- Work items or tasks -- break the feature up into the things that need to be done to implement it. Those parts might end up being done by different people, but we're mostly trying to understand the timeline for implementation. Dependencies ============ * Include specific references to specs and/or blueprints in keystone, or in other projects, that this one either depends on or is related to. * If this requires functionality of another project that is not currently used by Keystone (such as the glance v2 API when we previously only required v1), document that fact. * Does this feature require any new library dependencies or code otherwise not included in OpenStack? Or does it depend on a specific version of library? Documentation Impact ==================== What is the impact on the docs team of this change? Some changes might require donating resources to the docs team to have the documentation updated. Don't repeat details discussed above, but please reference them here. References ========== Please add any useful references here. You are not required to have any reference. Moreover, this specification should still make sense when your references are unavailable. Examples of what you could include are: * Links to mailing list or IRC discussions * Links to notes from a summit session * Links to relevant research, if appropriate * Related specifications as appropriate (e.g. if it's an EC2 thing, link the EC2 docs) * Anything else you feel it is worthwhile to refer to

commit_message:
Convert Exceptions to failures.

If evaluating a policy rule that throws an exception,
the policy engine gets the ability to manage the return message
and process any additional rules.

Closes-Bug: 1547684
Closes-Bug: 1459884

Change-Id: I5ec26b8ce72907a7ef5d319410c09a1c5a33d812

added_lines: def test_cleanly_handle_exceptions(self): check = _checks.RoleCheck('role', 'spam') self.assertFalse(check('target', dict(), self.enforcer)) self.assertFalse(check('target', None, self.enforcer)) @mock.patch.object(urlrequest, 'urlopen', return_value=six.StringIO('True')) def test_cleanly_handle_exception(self, mock_urlopen): check = _checks.HttpCheck('fargle', '') self.assertFalse(check(None, None, self.enforcer)) class _ExceptionCheck(_checks.Check): def __init__(self): super(_ExceptionCheck, self).__init__("", "") def __call__(self, target, cred, enforcer): raise Exception('ExceptionCheck') def test_exception_retuns_false(self): rules = [mock.Mock(return_value=True), _ExceptionCheck()] check = _checks.AndCheck(rules) self.assertFalse(check('target', 'cred', None)) rules[0].assert_called_once_with('target', 'cred', None) def test_exception_returns_false(self): rules = [mock.Mock(return_value=False), _ExceptionCheck()] check = _checks.OrCheck(rules) self.assertFalse(check('target', 'cred', None)) rules[0].assert_called_once_with('target', 'cred', None) def test_exception_returns_true(self): rules = [mock.Mock(return_value=True), _ExceptionCheck()] check = _checks.OrCheck(rules) self.assertTrue(check('target', 'cred', None)) rules[0].assert_called_once_with('target', 'cred', None)

commit_message:
Openvswitch: Move chart to openstack-helm-infra

This moves the openvswitch chart to openstack-helm-infra as part of
the effort to move charts to their appropriate repositories

Story: 2002204
Task: 21730

subject: Use templates for cover and lower-constraints
revisions:

Use openstack-tox-cover template, this runs the cover job
in the check queue only.

Use openstack-lower-constraints-jobs template

Remove jobs that are part of the templates.

Change-Id: I9075f2ded74aab0baa35e58298598b8e835d62e7

commit_message:
Use templates for cover and lower-constraints

Use openstack-tox-cover template, this runs the cover job
in the check queue only.

Use openstack-lower-constraints-jobs template

Remove jobs that are part of the templates.

Change-Id: I9075f2ded74aab0baa35e58298598b8e835d62e7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-tricircleclient refs/changes/35/600735/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: scripts: Fix getting external role SHA when working on master
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-08-30 14:53:57.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/6d8a07cec3819546ab8a70a6af89eb9f7d8d1698', 'message': "scripts: Fix getting external role SHA when working on master

When force_master == true, the code did not try to get tag information
from external roles but it tried to get the SHA for the specified
$osa_branch. External roles do not have stable/* branches, so the result
was an empty version. We fix that by simply falling back to master
branch if 'force_master' is set to True.

Change-Id: I73b8591217298511132d67f7a83ef27b093c02e4

commit_message:
scripts: Fix getting external role SHA when working on master

When force_master == true, the code did not try to get tag information
from external roles but it tried to get the SHA for the specified
$osa_branch. External roles do not have stable/* branches, so the result
was an empty version. We fix that by simply falling back to master
branch if 'force_master' is set to True.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/598246/
Change-Id: I73b8591217298511132d67f7a83ef27b093c02e4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/95/598195/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # If we are forcing master and we still don't have a role_version defined, then we need # to fallback to master branch if [[ -z "${role_version}" ]] && [[ "${force_master}" == "true" ]]; then role_version=$(git ls-remote ${role_src} | grep master | awk '{print $1}') fi

commit_message:
import zuul job settings from project-config

This is a mechanically generated patch to complete step 1 of moving
the zuul job settings out of project-config and into each project
repository.

Because there will be a separate patch on each branch, the branch
specifiers for branch-specific jobs have been removed.

Because this patch is generated by a script, there may be some
cosmetic changes to the layout of the YAML file(s) as the contents are
normalized.

See the python3-first goal document for details:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/stein/python3-first.html

commit_message:
Increase post-timeout for upgrade jobs from 30min to 40min

Upgrade jobs are likely to have more to collect in post and we
override the default 30min timout with 40mins, which is matching
old tripleo timeout for collection.

Change-Id: Ibabfcabfa370c3a512d0b2df65b4ccd8098a119a

commit_message:
Make sure the branch to track is in YAML

There is no reason to rely on comments in the files
used to bump the SHAs of upstream repositories.

Without this, a contributor can easily add a comment
and break the tooling, which relies on regexps and
well formated files to behave.

Instead, as this is a YAML file, we should rely on
a YAML parser in the release tooling, for more
robustness.

This fixes the issues by adding an extra key
(_git_track_branch) per repository, showing what to track.
This could be used in release tooling, and is not hurting
the existing code, as the extra keys are not loaded:
Those files are only consumed by the py_pkgs lookup, which
won't read this extra key.

Change-Id: I8fe08f389160e7be17dd56afde22173778540855
(manual cherry picked from commit 2a288e1b1e57d2986b25851b51613452c891f3e0)

commit_message:
Validate member address for lb graph creation

We added the configuration option for reserved IP addresses that cannot
be used for load balancer member addresses, but the validation for lb
graph creation is missing.

This patch should also be backported to stable branches.

Change-Id: I5ba30d29e7a35b370f21d9f68ec43efed74dd363
Story: 2003413
Task: 24555

commit_message:
import zuul job settings from project-config

This is a mechanically generated patch to complete step 1 of moving
the zuul job settings out of project-config and into each project
repository.

Because there will be a separate patch on each branch, the branch
specifiers for branch-specific jobs have been removed.

Because this patch is generated by a script, there may be some
cosmetic changes to the layout of the YAML file(s) as the contents are
normalized.

See the python3-first goal document for details:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/stein/python3-first.html

Add a fix for tox_install.sh to avoid it erroring out when called with
no arguments.

Change-Id: Icfa74452c3563dad50ea72b503012acc57d0636b
Story: #2002586
Task: #24320

covered by schema check, so no need to check it in testcases.

subject: Configure placement DB context manager for nova-manage/status
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-09-04 18:55:15.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/c595e75a886f5b7f0b7230157b6ed363eeaaf51d', 'message': "WIP: Swallow fewer exceptions in _run_migration

The generic Exception handling in here was swallowing
database errors due to misconfiguration of the engine
facade context manager. We missed this in CI because
we didn't treat it like an error.

This changes Exception to NovaException so that at
least DB failures bubble up.

Change-Id: I9d97b7a904e2b7d15c763e2a067cc5909cc6c9c5
Related-Bug: #1790701
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2018-09-04 20:05:27.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/0a448ce9c11807a600ca6e63d2841de872bd6b80', 'message': 'Configure placement DB context manager for online_data_migrations

The create_incomplete_consumers online data migration was added in
Rocky via change Id609789ef6b4a4c745550cde80dd49cabe03869a. That
relies on hitting some tables in the API (or placement) database.
The DB API code for that migration relies on a placement context
manager which looks like it was regressed with change
I2fff528060ec52a4a2e26a6484bdf18359b95f77 (also in Rocky). This
results in a DB error trying to query the projects table but
because of a generic try/except in _run_migration, the failure
was missed in CI testing.

This adds the configuration of the global placement DB API context
manager so we can properly query the placement-related tables.
The blanket problematic try/except is also removed because as
can be seen from this regression, it only masks bugs. If a migration
method raises an exception, we should halt.

Change-Id: I9d97b7a904e2b7d15c763e2a067cc5909cc6c9c5
Closes-Bug: #1790701
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2018-09-04 20:13:39.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/731ef425627ff87a22d6f8c9e401c5d3f0be4cb5', 'message': 'Configure placement DB context manager for online_data_migrations

relies on hitting some tables in the API (or placement) database.
The DB API code for that migration relies on a placement context
manager which looks like it was regressed with change
I2fff528060ec52a4a2e26a6484bdf18359b95f77 (also in Rocky). This
results in a DB error trying to query the projects table but
because of a generic try/except in _run_migration, the failure
was missed in CI testing.

This adds the configuration of the global placement DB API context
manager so we can properly query the placement-related tables.
The blanket problematic try/except is also removed because as
can be seen from this regression, it only masks bugs. If a migration
method raises an exception, we should halt.

Change-Id: I9d97b7a904e2b7d15c763e2a067cc5909cc6c9c5
Closes-Bug: #1790701
'}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2018-09-05 01:30:33.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/fb963986c208cde48193f04634ef4888960af625', 'message': 'Configure placement DB context manager for nova-manage/status

The create_incomplete_consumers online data migration was added in
Rocky via change Id609789ef6b4a4c745550cde80dd49cabe03869a. That
relies on hitting some tables in the API (or placement) database.
The DB API code for that migration relies on a placement context
manager which looks like it was regressed with change
I2fff528060ec52a4a2e26a6484bdf18359b95f77 (also in Rocky). This
results in a DB error trying to query the projects table but
because of a generic try/except in _run_migration, the failure
was missed in CI testing.

Similarly, the nova-status upgrade check "_check_resource_providers"
routine also uses the placement DB API context manager to count the
number of compute resource providers in the API (or placement) DB,
which is returning 0 because it's not using the proper DB connection.
This was not caught in the nova-status CLI tests because they use
the DatabaseFixture which *does* configure the global placement DB
API context manager.

This adds the configuration of the global placement DB API context
manager so we can properly query the placement-related tables.
The blanket problematic try/except from _run_migration is also removed
because as can be seen from this regression, it only masks bugs. If
a migration method raises an exception, we should halt.

Change-Id: I9d97b7a904e2b7d15c763e2a067cc5909cc6c9c5
Closes-Bug: #1790701
Closes-Bug: #1790721
'}, {'number': 5, 'created': '2018-09-05 14:41:29.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/unit/test_conf.py', 'nova/cmd/manage.py', 'nova/config.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/63c10d2d536c3ffed68ccfb6bd393f317111d903', 'message': 'Configure placement DB context manager for nova-manage/status

The create_incomplete_consumers online data migration was added in
Rocky via change Id609789ef6b4a4c745550cde80dd49cabe03869a. That
relies on hitting some tables in the API (or placement) database.
The DB API code for that migration relies on a placement context
manager which looks like it was regressed with change
I2fff528060ec52a4a2e26a6484bdf18359b95f77 (also in Rocky). This
results in a DB error trying to query the projects table but
because of a generic try/except in _run_migration, the failure
was missed in CI testing.

Similarly, the nova-status upgrade check "_check_resource_providers"
routine also uses the placement DB API context manager to count the
number of compute resource providers in the API (or placement) DB,
which is returning 0 because it's not using the proper DB connection.
This was not caught in the nova-status CLI tests because they use
the DatabaseFixture which *does* configure the global placement DB
API context manager.

This adds the configuration of the global placement DB API context
manager so we can properly query the placement-related tables.
The blanket problematic try/except from _run_migration is left
as-is in this change but will be addressed in a separate patch.

Integration testing of this fix is being performed with devstack:

  https://review.openstack.org/599847/

Change-Id: I9d97b7a904e2b7d15c763e2a067cc5909cc6c9c5
Closes-Bug: #1790701
Closes-Bug: #1790721
'}]
commit_message:
Configure placement DB context manager for nova-manage/status

The create_incomplete_consumers online data migration was added in
Rocky via change Id609789ef6b4a4c745550cde80dd49cabe03869a. That
relies on hitting some tables in the API (or placement) database.
The DB API code for that migration relies on a placement context
manager which looks like it was regressed with change
I2fff528060ec52a4a2e26a6484bdf18359b95f77 (also in Rocky). This
results in a DB error trying to query the projects table but
because of a generic try/except in _run_migration, the failure
was missed in CI testing.

Similarly, the nova-status upgrade check "_check_resource_providers"
routine also uses the placement DB API context manager to count the
number of compute resource providers in the API (or placement) DB,
which is returning 0 because it's not using the proper DB connection.
This was not caught in the nova-status CLI tests because they use
the DatabaseFixture which *does* configure the global placement DB
API context manager.

This adds the configuration of the global placement DB API context
manager so we can properly query the placement-related tables.
The blanket problematic try/except from _run_migration is left
as-is in this change but will be addressed in a separate patch.

Integration testing of this fix is being performed with devstack:

  https://review.openstack.org/599847/

Change-Id: I9d97b7a904e2b7d15c763e2a067cc5909cc6c9c5
Closes-Bug: #1790701
Closes-Bug: #1790721

commit_message:
remove job settings for watcher repositories

This is a mechanically generated patch to remove the job settings that
have been migrated to the git repositories owned by the watcher team.

See the python3-first goal document for details:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/stein/python3-first.html

Change-Id: I948b75e937fd83d29d566407b6d97293227ddcfb

commit_message:
Unify utils.py and util.py

The "util.py" is from nova/api/openstack/placement/util.py.
The "utils.py" is from nova/utils.py.

In this patch, we move the method of utils.py into util.py,
and cleanup the utils.py.

Change-Id: I92c3f90897fea4b2d2f6eb2cd44b27cfa6456ee8

commit_message:
Rename PlacementPolicyFixture to PolicyFixture

The "PlacementPolicyFixture" is used for distinguish between
nova and placement, and we can use PolicyFixture after placement
extraction directly.

In this patch, we rename PlacementPolicyFixture to PolicyFixture

Change-Id: I6d799c5a6c8a130c7d101dc29a86456f1bf12c24

commit_message:
fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: I364586e2a0cf15bb24fa72f7b49c4701a581f4c4
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Add confluent-kafka to global-requirements

* Is the library actively maintained?
Yes, it's maintained by Confluent.

* Is the library good code?
Yes, it's a recommended Python Kafka client.

* Is the library python 3 compatible?
Yes.

* Is the library license compatible?
Yes, Apache-2.

* Is the library already packaged in the distros we target (Ubuntu
  latest / Fedora latest)?

Partially:
  Ubuntu [1]
  SUSE (unofficial) [2]

[1] https://packages.ubuntu.com/bionic/python-confluent-kafka
[2] https://build.opensuse.org/package/show/home:jgrassler:branches:devel:languages:python/python-confluent-kafka

* Is the function of this library already covered by other libraries in
global-requirements.txt?

Partially. Confluent-kafka is a Python wrapper around librdkafka which
provides full Kafka protocol support with great performance compared to
the kafka-python.

Confluent-kafka is about to replace not used in OpenStack PyKafka [3].

[3] https://review.openstack.org/585398

* Is the library required for OpenStack project or related dev or
infrastructure setup?

Yes, Monasca.

Change-Id: I5f0756ee796cb1d59a8a2a9c1c51b746f019ec39

commit_message:
Remove PyKafka from global-requirements

PyKafka was added to g-r as planned replacement for kafka-python client
in Monasca [1]. Support for this client was never added though and the
library is not used. Recent tests have shown that confluent-kafka client
provides better throughtput and Kafka API support. Current plan is to
add support for confluent-kafka client in Monasca instead of PyKafka
[2].

No other project uses PyKafka [3].

[1] https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/requirements/commit/?id=c1749152a85a80180198a5985d34d3ab86aeb722
[2] https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/story/2003079
[3] http://codesearch.openstack.org/?q=pykafka&i=nope&files=&repos=

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/585374
Change-Id: I91202fc1187c284c0fd994ad7d8bd649f5973196

To enable the plugin, add the following to your local.conf: enable_plugin searchlight-ui <searchlight-ui GITURL> [GITREF] where <searchlight-ui GITURL> is the URL of a searchlight-ui repository [GITREF] is an optional git ref (branch/ref/tag). The default is master. For example: enable_plugin searchlight-ui https://git.openstack.org/openstack/searchlight-ui This plugin also depends on the following services to be enabled: ``horizon``, ``searchlight-api``, and ``searchlight-listener``. * https://github.com/openstack/searchlight/tree/master/devstack

commit_message:
templates: openrc: Use 'true' and 'false' for insecure env variables

It seems that most tools are expecting a literal 'true' or 'false' value
for env variables, so use that instead of '1' and empty values.

Change-Id: I36c5460165dba6acd1b94e82c712312f9fd307a9
(cherry picked from commit 82730e54cf4dfc7c2f507e067dff53d10ffb36d0)

subject: Optimizes volume creation in the Quobyte Driver
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-09-05 12:03:02.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/49afe1f3628b8c221df8240f083381c3e2632644', 'message': "Optimizes volume creation in the Quobyte Driver

This change takes two steps to optimize the creation
of volumes with the Quobyte driver:
1. It removes a superfluous create_volume call during creation of
a new volume from an snapshot. This creation result is not used with
Quobyte but subsequently overwritten by the following qemu-img convert
operation.
2. It changes the creation of qcow2 and regular file based volumes. For
regular files fallocate is used instead of writing the file via dd. For
qcow2 the qemu-img create (prealloc=metadata) command is followed up by
a truncate on the resulting volume file. This prevents io serialization
issues with fuse later on which may impact performance when content is
written to a qcow2 file beyond it's current eof.

Change-Id: I8a922f4a7a9e62658469ef31eb55c6d4b9ab8477
Partial-Bug: #1715078

commit_message:
Optimizes volume creation in the Quobyte Driver

This change takes two steps to optimize the creation
of volumes with the Quobyte driver:
1. It removes a superfluous create_volume call during creation of
a new volume from an snapshot. This creation result is not used with
Quobyte but subsequently overwritten by the following qemu-img convert
operation.
2. It changes the creation regular file based volumes. For
regular files fallocate is used instead of writing the file via dd.

Partial-Bug: #1715078

Change-Id: I8a922f4a7a9e62658469ef31eb55c6d4b9ab8477

commit_message:
Release oslo.service 1.32.0

We'd like to raise constraints to eventlet 0.24.1 and oslo.service
had failures related to that in tests. this update includes
the fixes for that.

Change-Id: I29871582fc04435c777bc40a86c5f59f43f803ad

commit_message:
Add encrypted volume support to feature matrix docs

Native QEMU LUKS decryption support was added for the
libvirt driver in Queens, but there are no docs in the
feature support matrix about encrypted volume support
at all, so this attempts to close that gap.

Change-Id: I035164a0c4222814784306381f9a11413c8de9e2

added_lines: [operation.encrypted-volume] title=Attach encrypted block volume to server status=optional notes=This is the same as the attach volume operation except with an encrypted block device. Encrypted volumes are controlled via admin-configured volume types in the block storage service. Since attach volume is optional this feature is also optional for compute drivers to support. cli=nova volume-attach <server> <volume> driver-impl-xenserver=missing driver-impl-libvirt-kvm-x86=complete driver-notes-libvirt-kvm-x86=For native QEMU decryption of the encrypted volume (and rbd support), QEMU>=2.6.0 and libvirt>=2.2.0 are required and only the "luks" type provider is supported. Otherwise both "luks" and "cryptsetup" types are supported but not natively, i.e. not all volume types are supported. driver-impl-libvirt-kvm-aarch64=unknown driver-impl-libvirt-kvm-ppc64=unknown driver-impl-libvirt-kvm-s390x=unknown driver-impl-libvirt-qemu-x86=complete driver-notes-libvirt-qemu-x86=The same restrictions apply as KVM x86. driver-impl-libvirt-lxc=missing driver-impl-libvirt-xen=unknown driver-impl-vmware=missing driver-impl-hyperv=missing driver-impl-ironic=missing driver-impl-libvirt-vz-vm=unknown driver-impl-libvirt-vz-ct=missing driver-impl-powervm=missing

commit_message:
Docs: update link for remote debugging

The section on remote debugging points to a blog post that not longer
exists. This updates the invalid link.

The patch also adds in some new lines and bullets.
TrivialFix

Change-Id: I8b29f402f148bc11279a2c34aeea266956180bc1

commit_message:
import zuul job settings from project-config

This is a mechanically generated patch to complete step 1 of moving
the zuul job settings out of project-config and into each project
repository.

Because there will be a separate patch on each branch, the branch
specifiers for branch-specific jobs have been removed.

Because this patch is generated by a script, there may be some
cosmetic changes to the layout of the YAML file(s) as the contents are
normalized.

See the python3-first goal document for details:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/stein/python3-first.html

Change-Id: Idc76f65fc4747e3d15f835e56648df2e628c0808
Story: #2002586
Task: #24314

commit_message:
Update volume-attachment API url in policies

Correct url is /servers/{server_id}/os-volume_attachments/{volume_id} [1].
'volume_id' and 'attachment_id' are conceptually different.

[1] https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/#show-a-detail-of-a-volume-attachment

Change-Id: Idbb165d8b695f5609306ddc678d0ad6fc559ab7e

commit_message:
DVR: Add IPv6 csnat port address correctly

If router gateway info update, in l3_dvr_db will receive events,
We will get subnets from router attached DVR port, if exists
multiple IPv6 slaac-enabled subnets, previous code will create
csnat port form one of the IPv6 subnets.
This is inconsistency with router interface
udpate in _update_snat_v6_addrs_after_intf_update.

This patch adds all IPv6 subnets if the distributed
router port have multiple IPv6 subnets.

Change-Id: I02ffed238897ebc91b96aebb7f94ed90b7613769
Closes-Bug: #1786169
(cherry picked from commit c6aac9041f98f971cd1362bee2768a04bbe5cf1d)

commit_message:
Specification for Port Monitoring driver in Tacker

Change-Id: I0e5623c11ecb4c7c15060057f6e3cd8ffbf278e8
Implements: blueprint  port-monitoring-driver
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tacker-specs refs/changes/95/558795/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================================================== Port Monitoring driver in Tacker ============================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/tacker/+spec/port-monitoring-driver This driver is Port monitoring drivers for checking application Status(VNFC). Problem description =================== In the ETSI, when designing and developing the software that provides the VNF, VNF Providers may structure that software into software components and package those components into one or more images. In the following, these VNF Provider defined software components are called VNF Components(VNFCs). Now, Tacker also supported VNFC. Therefore tacker need a VNFC monitoring tool and it also can check the status of application which run on the VNF too. Proposed change =============== Tacker is a MANO that it has a role to manage VNF life cycle. Tacker now support several monitoring tools to check the status of VNF. However, Simple monitoring tools also necessary to check the status of application. Currently, Tacker support monitoring drivers which could check network(ping) and application(using HTTP URL). Therefore, port monitoring driver helps to check the status application. Moreover,it helps for auto healing of VNFC level. Alternatives ------------ we also can use another way to check application status such as checking P-ID Additionally, Thoes method should send command message or installed agent in VNF for checking status. However,port scanning driver can check VNFC Status using port scanning without any installation. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ This monitoring driver can check every sec(min). User can change the Monitoring time with VNFD. The example of the descriptor below: tosca_definitions_version: tosca_simple_profile_for_nfv_1_0_0 description: Demo example metadata: template_name: sample-tosca-vnfd topology_template: node_templates: VDU1: type: tosca.nodes.nfv.VDU.Tacker properties: image: cirros-0.3.5-x86_64-disk flavor: m1.tiny availability_zone: nova mgmt_driver: noop config: | param0: key1 param1: key2 monitoring_policy: name: port parameters: monitoring_delay: 45 count: 3 timeout: 1 sockmode: 1 scanports: 22 actions: failure: respawn CP1: type: tosca.nodes.nfv.CP.Tacker properties: management: true anti_spoofing_protection: false requirements: - virtualLink: node: VL1 - virtualBinding: node: VDU1 VL1: type: tosca.nodes.nfv.VL properties: network_name: net_mgmt vendor: Tacker count ==> number of ICMP packets to send timeout ==> number of seconds to wait for a response sockmode ==> socket mode of TCP, UDP(TCP:1, UDP:0) scanports ==> number of Target port Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: hyunsik yang Work Items ---------- None Dependencies ============ Testing ======= We verify this monitoring driver in the openstack master version. (2018-04-04) Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== [1] http://docs.oasis-open.org/tosca/tosca-nfv/v1.0/tosca-nfv-v1.0.pdf

subject: Implement Tacker Server to support VNF cluster features
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-12-22 08:37:42.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tacker/commit/f149d6c4d042747edb9edca9d68459038c42b640', 'message': 'Implement Tacker Server to support VNF cluster features

Adding new features to support VNF deployment in form of ACTIVE members and STANDBY members in cluster that guarantee High Availability to required VNF in Tacker env.

This implementation enable some cluster-related operation such as: VNF cluster and VNF cluster-member CRUD operations.

On the other hand, this implementation also introduce a new "respawn" action in policy action whose name "recovery". "Recovery" action will be triggered in the event of receiving event from monitoring drivers. The recovery scenarios is depend on asssigned role of the failed cluster-member in the system.
- In the case of failed cluster-member has ACTIVE role-> bring existing STANDBY member up to ACTIVE member -> deploy a new STANDBY member -> delete the failed member
- In the case of failed cluster-member has STANDBY role -> deploy a new STANDBY member -> delete a failed member.

blueprint: policy-based-vnf-cluster

Change-Id: Iecd89d7be5d1c88a06a405a0fba456b09cba9e6d
Co-Authored-By: xuan0802 <thespring1989@gmail.com>
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2017-12-22 11:35:37.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tacker/commit/541c8992d658c1f08a437dfcacae962ccbe06005', 'message': 'Implement Tacker Server to support VNF cluster features

Adding new features to support VNF deployment in form of ACTIVE members and STANDBY members in cluster that guarantee High Availability to required VNF in Tacker env.

This implementation enable some cluster-related operation such as: VNF cluster and VNF cluster-member CRUD operations.

On the other hand, this implementation also introduce a new "respawn" action in policy action whose name "recovery". "Recovery" action will be triggered in the event of receiving event from monitoring drivers. The recovery scenarios is depend on asssigned role of the failed cluster-member in the system.
- In the case of failed cluster-member has ACTIVE role-> bring existing STANDBY member up to ACTIVE member -> deploy a new STANDBY member -> delete the failed member
- In the case of failed cluster-member has STANDBY role -> deploy a new STANDBY member -> delete a failed member.

blueprint: policy-based-vnf-cluster

Change-Id: Iecd89d7be5d1c88a06a405a0fba456b09cba9e6d
Co-Authored-By: xuan0802 <thespring1989@gmail.com>

STANDBY member -> delete a failed member.

blueprint: policy-based-vnf-cluster

Change-Id: Iecd89d7be5d1c88a06a405a0fba456b09cba9e6d

commit_message:
Implement Tacker Server to support VNF cluster features

Adding new features to support VNF deployment in form of ACTIVE members
and STANDBY members in cluster that guarantee High Availability to required
VNF in Tacker env.
This implementation enable some cluster-related operation such as: VNF
cluster and VNF cluster-member CRUD operations.
On the other hand, this implementation also introduce a new monitoring
action in policy action whose name "recovery". "Recovery" action will be
triggered in the event of receiving event from monitoring drivers. The
recovery scenarios is depend on asssigned role of the failed cluster-member
in the system.
- In the case of failed cluster-member has ACTIVE role-> bring existing
STANDBY member up to ACTIVE member -> deploy a new STANDBY member -> delete
the failed member
- In the case of failed cluster-member has STANDBY role -> deploy a new
STANDBY member -> delete a failed member.

blueprint: policy-based-vnf-cluster

Change-Id: Iecd89d7be5d1c88a06a405a0fba456b09cba9e6d
Co-Authored-By: xuan0802 <thespring1989@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: HyunsikYang <yangun@dcn.ssu.ac.kr>

subject: Enabling policy-based clustering service for VNFs in Tacker
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-09-09 06:42:00.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tacker-specs/commit/ec9761a8031c724789be452d5bd0aee7588623b4', 'message': 'Enabling VNF cluster management

This spec describes the plan to add VNF cluster management function into NFV
Orchestrator (NFVO). This function is used to manage a cluster of Active and
Standby VNFs in order to provide the high availability for VNF. This function
also supports policy-based clustering management for VNFs.

blueprint: policy-based-vnf-cluster

Change-Id: I1d19e0278687b87d340e9021551227dba2b642c9
Co-Authored-By: xuan0802 <thespring1989@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Enabling policy-based clustering service for VNFs in Tacker

This spec describes the plan to add clustering service for VNFs into NFVO.
This function is used to manage a cluster of Active and Standby VNFs in
order to provide the high availability for VNFs.

blueprint: policy-based-vnf-cluster

Change-Id: I1d19e0278687b87d340e9021551227dba2b642c9
Co-Authored-By: xuan0802 <thespring1989@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: HyunsikYang <yangun@dcn.ssu.ac.kr>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tacker-specs refs/changes/16/502216/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ==================================================== Enable policy-based VNF cluster management in Tacker ==================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/tacker/+spec/policy-based-vnf-cluster This spec describes the plan to add VNF cluster management function into NFV Orchestrator (NFVO). This function is used to manage a cluster of Active and Standby VNFs in order to provide the high availability for VNF. This function also supports policy-based clustering management for VNFs. Problem description =================== In Telco environment, the reliability of network service (NS) is highly required. Beside auto-healing and auto-scaling solutions, traditional redundancy configuration methods, such as Active-Active or Active-Standby (form a high availability cluster) could be applied to VNFs to ensure the reliability of the NS. These high availability cluster configurations enable fast recovery of VNFs operation in case of failure. Operators will need a way to deploy and manage such kind of high availability clusters via NFVO component. Refer to ETSI-REL [#first]_ for VNF protection schemes in NFV system. The challenge of high availability cluster deployment involves several requirements that need to be handled by the NFV component as described as below: * Resource usage information of each VIM and availability zone for optimal cluster member placement * NFVO should find optimal locations for cluster members (based on predefined policies or dynamic network condition and resource usage status) * Load balancing strategies and monitoring strategies (heartbeat between cluster members or from NFVO) Currently, in Tacker, there is no feature to create and manage such kind of high availability clusters. With this proposal, we intend to allow Tacker users to create and manage such kind of high availability clusters. This function enables Tacker to deploy a cluster of Active and Stanby VNFs based on predefined operator polices. These high availability policies includes VNF placement locations (i.e. availability zones, VIMs), load balancer configuration, and recovery actions which are going to be triggered when failure occurs. Proposed change =============== The proposed component in NFVO to support high availability cluster management is shown as below figure: :: +--------------------------------------+ +--------------------------+ | NFVO | | VNFM | | | | | | +-----------------+ +--------------+ | | +-----------------------+| | | HA Policy | | Cluster | | | | Monitoring || | | | | engine | | | | Driver || | +-----------------+ | +----------+ | | | | Framework || | |-| Action |-| | | Cluster | | | | | || | |-----------------| | +----------+ | | | | || | |-----------------| | +----------+ | | | |+-----+ +----+ +----+ || | |-| Placement |-| | | Member | | | | || | | | | | || | |-| strategies |-| | +----------+ | | | ||Alarm| |Ping| |HTTP| || | |-----------------| | +----------+ | | | || | | | |Ping| || | |-----------------| | | HA Policy <------|| | | | | | || | |-|Load balancer|-| | +-----^----+ | | | |+-----+ +----+ +----+ || | |-| strategies |-| | | | | | +-----------------------+| | |-----------------| | | | | | | | +-----------------+ +-------|------+ | | | | | | | | | | +------------------+ | | | +--------------------------------------+ +--------------------------+ The high level changes needed to Tacker aim at accommodating a new feature in VNF cluster management will include changes to Tacker Client and Tacker Server. The changes include: * Adding a vnf-cluster REST APIs to Tacker Client which a client can use to CRUD cluster via command line interface. The client can use the REST APIs to deploy VNF cluster from VNFD (or even existing VNF). The created cluster shoud include (1) The created VNFs that are added to cluster as cluster members, these VNFs must be deployed from the same VNFD, (2) The Neutron load balancer that connects to cluster members aiming at loadbalancing traffic among cluster members, and (3) the attached HA policy (Be described in detail as below). The proposed operations are: .. code-block:: console tacker vnf-cluster create tacker vnf-cluster show tacker vnf-cluster list tacker vnf-cluster update tacker vnf-cluster delete * In order to make cluster creation become more flexible, policy is proposed as a new component in NFVO, Tacker Client changes will be made to include policy CRUD operations that REST API request to Tacker server. The policy should include a pre-defined recovery action, placement strategies of cluster members, and the load balancer strategies. A typical **policy-create** command can be described as below: .. code-block:: console tacker policy-create --name policySample --policy-file ~/policySample.yaml * The **--policy-file** argument will take policy information via a yaml file. * The policy can be processed as an input in vnf-cluster creation command via multiple ways, including (1) an ID or name of policy that has been already stored in Tacker database, as well as (2) a policy template that defines policy parameters in form of yaml file. This spec aims at implementing vnf cluster creation in NFVO using (1) as the first priority. * Tacker Server will also need to modify the NFVO extentions and NFVO plugin in order to incorperate vnf-cluster operations and policy resources. * The drivers for vnf-cluster will need to be written in order to handle both of vnf-cluster and policy CRUD operations. Note that this spec is supposed to only provide vnf-cluster management in single site, multi-site support will be considered in the future. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- Data model impact includes the creation of **vnf_cluster**, **vnf_cluster_members**, **policy** tables. * The **policy** table will store all of the imported policy attributes from yaml file. These policy attributes will be queried during vnf-cluster deployment in order to deploy the Neutron load balancer, as well as indicate to the NFVO know about which availability zone the cluster members shoud deploy on. * The **vnf_cluster** table will hold all the relevant attributes of vnf-cluster resource, while the attributes of the vnf-cluster members that belong to the created vnf-cluster are stored in the **vnf_cluster_members** table and has a **vnf_cluster_id** attribute which is mapped to the **vnf_cluster** resouce. REST API impact --------------- Because the policy needs to be defined and attached to a vnf-cluster, the policy object needs to be created first, then it will be passed to vnf-cluster creation command as an argument. The sample of configuration file for policy creation is shown as below: .. code-block:: yaml description: An example of clustering policy descriptor properties: action: failure: recovery placement: active: availability_zone: az1: 1 az2: 1 standby: availability_zone: az1: 1 load_balancer: properties: pool: protocol: HTTP protocol_port: 80 subnet: tacker-subnet lb_method: ROUND_ROBIN vip: subnet: tacker-subnet protocol: HTTP protocol_port: 80 The policy contains **action**, **placement** and **load_balancer** attributes. The **action** in policy template describes which action shoud be executed in the event of the monitoring driver trigger an event. The **placement** attribute indicates which availability zone the VNF should deploy on and which member roles (Active or Standby) will be taken by VNFs. Note that deployment of vnf-cluster over multi-VIMs is outside of the scope in this spec, but it might be extended to support multi-VIMs cluster deployment later. The **load_balancer** attribute contains configured parameters that will be used to invoke Neutron client for deploying a Neutron load balancer. Because the VNF is treated as a cluster member - a basic unit in vnf-cluster, in order to deploy the vnf-cluster the VNFD template need to be created by the client first. There is no extension of the VNFD compared to the original one. Example of vnf-cluster creation CLI: To create policy: .. code-block:: console tacker policy-create --name policy_sample --policy-file ~/policy_sample.yaml To create vnf-cluster: .. code-block:: console tacker vnf-cluster create --name cluster_sample --vnfd-name vnfd_sample --policy-name policy_sample At vnf-cluster creation time, the NFVO plugin will query VNFM to find available VNFD resouces that exist from provided VNFD ID. It also queries policy in order to deploy vnf-cluster by following the defined configuration. New 'nfvo' extension will be introduced in Tacker API v1 that implements REST API end point for **policy** and **vnf-cluster** resources as described below: .. csv-table:: **/policy** :header: Attribute Name,Type,Access,Default, Validation Conversion,Des id,String (UUID),"RO, All",generated,N/A,identity name,string,"RW, All","None, (Required)",string,human-readable name description, string, "RW, All", None, string, description of policy attributes, dict,"RW, All", None, dict, "policy template" tenant_id, String (UUID), "RW, All", "None, (Required)", uuid, "tenant ID to launch policy" .. csv-table:: **/vnf_cluster** :header: Attribute Name,Type,Access,Default, Validation Conversion,Des id, string (UUID),"RO, All",generated,N/A,identity name, string,"RW, All","None, (Required)",string,human-readable name description, string, "RW, All", None, string, description of cluster status, string, "RO, All", generated, string, Status of created cluster vnfd_id, string (UUID), "RO, All", None (Required), uuid, VNFD ID to use to deploy cluster members policy_id, string (UUID), "RO, All", None (Required), uuid, policy ID that will be attached to cluster lb_id, string (UUID), "RO, All", generated, uuid, ID of created load balancer tenant_id, String (UUID), "RW, All", "None, (Required)", uuid, "tenant ID to launch vnf-cluster" .. csv-table:: **/vnf_cluster/members** :header: Attribute Name,Type,Access,Default, Validation Conversion,Des id,string (UUID),"RO, All",generated,N/A,identity cluster_id, string (UUID), "RO, All", generated, uuid, ID of associated cluster member_index, integer, "RO, All", generated, integer, index of member in cluster role, string, "RW, All", generated, String, Role of member in cluster status, string, "RO, All", generated, string, Status of created cluster placement_attr, string, "RW, All", None (Required), string, availability zone where cluster member is deployed on vnfd_id, String (UUID), "RO, All", None (Required), uuid, VNFD ID to use to deploy cluster members tenant_id, String (UUID), "RW, All", "None, (Required)", uuid, "tenant ID to launch cluster member" Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- There will be changes to python-tackerclient for the end user in order to manage policy, vnf-cluster and vnf-cluster members. The changes will involve adding new shell extensions to python-tackerclient in order to allow CRUD operations for policy, vnf-cluster and vnf-cluster members. Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- **neutron-lbaas** should be installed to make this feature work, so it is necessary to update the tacker's Devstack installation procedure in the script and the manual installation guideline. Because **neutron-lbaas** resources are queried in order to deploy load balancer during vnf-cluster creation by using Neutron client. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- primary author and contact. Primary assignee: longkb <longkb@bka.vn> xuan0802 <thespring1989@gmail.com> Work Items ---------- * Implement policy concept in Tacker NFVO * Implement vnf-cluster for VNF from VNFD and associated policy * Update Devstack installation procedure and manual installation guideline for Tacker * Add unit test and function test for policy and vnf-cluster * Add guideline for how to use vnf-cluster feature Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= * Add function test for vnf-cluster * Add sample configuration file for policy Documentation Impact ==================== Update documentation for vnf vnf-cluster and add new documentation. References ========== .. [#first] http://www.etsi.org/deliver/etsi_gs/NFV-REL/001_099/003/01.01.01_60 /gs_nfv-rel003v010101p.pdf

subject: Add supporting --availability-zone to vnf-create function in Tacker Server
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-01-12 17:22:36.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tacker/commit/81b7b01354367865d247bb6a55d85fb7653009ec', 'message': 'Add --vim-az support to vnf-create function in Tacker Server

Currently, Tacker only support client to define the indicated availabilty-zone in VNFD.
It is not support client to specify availability-zone directly via CLI. The main problem
is VNFD only suitable to deploy VNFs with the same availability-zone. It cannot be used
to define a group of VNFs that are distributed across different zones. This feature
could be used to enable high availability of VNFs over multiple availability-zones.
In particular, we enhance create_vnf function in VNFM to support --az-attr argument.

Implements: availability-zone-support-in-vnf-creation

Change-Id: I3b73f0e327280e91826be6106389be20d6f68f7c
Co-Authored-By: xuan0802 <thespring1989@gmail.com>

to define a group of VNFs that are distributed across different zones. This feature
could be used to enable high availability of VNFs over multiple availability-zones.
In particular, we enhance create_vnf function in VNFM to support --az-attr argument.

blueprint: availability-zone-support-in-vnf-creation

Currently, Tacker only support client to define the indicated availabilty-zone in VNFD.
It is not support client to specify availability-zone directly via CLI. The main problem

commit_message:
Add supporting --availability-zone to vnf-create function in Tacker
Server

Currently, Tacker only support client to define the indicated
Availabilty Zone in VNFD or through parameter file.

It is not supported by Tacker client to specify Availability Zone
directly via CLI. The main problem is VNFD only suitable to deploy
VNFs with the same Availability Zone. It can not be used to define
a group of VNFs that are distributed across different zones. This
feature could be used to enable high availability of VNFs over
multiple availability-zones. In particular, we enhance vnf-create
function in VNFM to support --availability-zone argument to override
Availability Zone value.

e.g. tacker vnf-create --vnfd-name VNFD1 --availability-zone nova VNF1

Co-Authored-By: Cong Phuoc Hoang <hoangphuocbk2.07@gmail.com>

blueprint: availability-zone-support-in-vnf-creation

Change-Id: I3b73f0e327280e91826be6106389be20d6f68f7c
Co-Authored-By: xuan0802 <thespring1989@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Support exposing Kubernetes service using Loadbalancer with devstack

This patch will do 2 things:
1. Simplify Tacker K8s VIM installation in devstack using 'public'
default network.
2. Update Tacker devstack to follow Kuryr kubernetes installation
with support expose Kubernetes service using Loadbalancer type

This patch also fix the bug of missing
KURYR_NEUTRON_DEFAULT_EXT_SVC_NET net (public) when deploying
tacker with k8s vim enabled using devstack due to the recent changes
of the kuryr-kubernetes project.

Partially Implements: blueprint kuryr-kubernetes-integration

commit_message:
Misc updates for DPDK support

Fix use of OVS DPDK context by direct use of methods on context
for OVS table values.

For modern OVS versions that require the PCI address of the
DPDK device for type=dpdk ports, use a hash of the PCI address
for the port name rather than the index of the PCI device in
the current list of devices to use; this is idempotent in the
event that the configuration changes and new devices appear
in the list of devices to use for DPDK.

Only set OVS table values if the value has changed; OVS will
try to re-allocate hugepage memory, irrespective as to whether
the table value actually changed.

Switch to using /run/libvirt-vhost-user for libvirt created DPDK
sockets, allowing libvirt to directly create the socket as part
of instance creation; Use systemd-tmpfiles to ensure that the
vhost-user subdirectory is re-created on boot with the correct
permissions.

Scan data-port and dpdk-bond-mappings for PCI devices to use
for DPDK to avoid having to replicate all PCI devices in data-port
configuration when DPDK bonds are in use.

Change-Id: I2964046bc8681fa870d61c6cd23b6ad6fee47bf4

commit_message:
Increase delayed_calls_v2.auth_context

When the keystone catalog gets big, no execution can be made because the
catalog cannot fit in the `auth_context` field.

Change-Id: I100494e467f43386be17eb397fbdf0a0edd24453
Closes-Bug: 1785654
(cherry picked from commit 1f8ae7fc863d77a9ad722bd0dec7c41c26235400)

commit_message:
Use templates for cover and lower-constraints

Use openstack-tox-cover template, this runs the cover job as
non-voting in the check queue only.

Use openstack-lower-constraints-jobs template

Remove jobs that are part of the templates.

Remove also branches conditions, these are ignored - zuul templates are
defined on each branch instead.

Change-Id: Ia9ec0ce177b1a01aee783d38c85738b05b41fca3

subject: Avoid release_vif race when using namespaces and pools
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-09-06 06:45:29.000000000', 'files': ['kuryr_kubernetes/controller/handlers/vif.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kuryr-kubernetes/commit/37a7112e58e7568b8ba68e863b965ee2c164d794', 'message': 'Avoid release_vif race when using namespaces and pools

If ports pools and namespace isolation features are enabled together
it may happen that namespace object gets deleted before the vif handler
on_delete function gets executed, leading to a ResourceNotReady
exception raised by the namespace security group driver when trying
to get the kuryrnet crd annotated on the (deleted) namespace object.

This patch ensure if that happens, the vif handler can still complete
the on_deleted function, releasing the vif by using an empty security
group list as the ports are going to be deleted anyway with the rest
of the namespace related OpenStack resources.

Closes-Bug: 1787951
Change-Id: I19a8f89fb13de1b43e2f6178b6b0261f5dde7990
(cherry picked from commit e3a33599a3a3657affdf64ce6c38cd4707158628)
'}]
commit_message:
Avoid release_vif race when using namespaces and pools

If ports pools and namespace isolation features are enabled together
it may happen that namespace object gets deleted before the vif handler
on_delete function gets executed, leading to a ResourceNotReady
exception raised by the namespace security group driver when trying
to get the kuryrnet crd annotated on the (deleted) namespace object.

This patch ensure if that happens, the vif handler can still complete
the on_deleted function, releasing the vif by using an empty security
group list as the ports are going to be deleted anyway with the rest
of the namespace related OpenStack resources.

Closes-Bug: 1787951
Change-Id: I19a8f89fb13de1b43e2f6178b6b0261f5dde7990
(cherry picked from commit e3a33599a3a3657affdf64ce6c38cd4707158628)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kuryr-kubernetes refs/changes/47/600347/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: try: security_groups = self._drv_sg.get_security_groups(pod, project_id) except k_exc.ResourceNotReady: # NOTE(ltomasbo): If the namespace object gets deleted first the # namespace security group driver will raise a ResourceNotReady # exception as it cannot access anymore the kuryrnet CRD annotated # on the namespace object. In such case we set security groups to # empty list so that if pools are enabled they will be properly # released. security_groups = []

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/metalsmith refs/changes/88/599688/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import os import requestsfrom six.moves.urllib import parse as urlparse from metalsmith import _utils class Http(_Source): """Image from HTTP(s) location. Some deployment methods require a checksum of the image. It has to be provided via ``checksum`` or ``checksum_url``. For partition images ``kernel_url`` and ``ramdisk_url`` have to be provided. Only ``checksum_url`` (if provided) has to be accessible from the current machine. Other URLs have to be accessible by the Bare Metal service (more specifically, by **ironic-conductor** processes). """ def __init__(self, url, checksum=None, checksum_url=None, kernel_url=None, ramdisk_url=None): """Create an HTTP source. :param url: URL of the image. :param checksum: MD5 checksum of the image. Mutually exclusive with ``checksum_url``. :param checksum_url: URL of the checksum file for the image. Has to be in the standard format of the ``md5sum`` tool. Mutually exclusive with ``checksum``. :param kernel_url: URL of the kernel image. Only for partition images. :param ramdisk_url: URL of the initramfs image. Only for partition images. """ if (checksum and checksum_url) or (not checksum and not checksum_url): raise TypeError('Exactly one of checksum and checksum_url has ' 'to be specified') self.url = url self.checksum = checksum self.checksum_url = checksum_url self.kernel_url = kernel_url self.ramdisk_url = ramdisk_url def _validate(self, api): # TODO(dtantsur): should we validate image URLs here? Ironic will do it # as well, and images do not have to be accessible from where # metalsmith is running. if self.checksum: return try: checksums = requests.get(self.checksum_url).text except requests.RequestException as exc: raise exceptions.InvalidImage( 'Cannot download checksum file %(url)s: %(err)s' % {'url': self.checksum_url, 'err': exc}) checksums = _utils.parse_checksums(checksums) fname = os.path.basename(urlparse.urlparse(self.url).path) try: self.checksum = checksums[fname] except KeyError: raise exceptions.InvalidImage( 'There is no image checksum for %(fname)s in %(url)s' % {'fname': fname, 'url': self.checksum_url}) def _node_updates(self, api): self._validate(api) LOG.debug('Image: %(image)s, checksum %(checksum)s', {'image': self.url, 'checksum': self.checksum}) updates = { '/instance_info/image_source': self.url, '/instance_info/image_checksum': self.checksum, } if self.kernel_url: updates['/instance_info/kernel'] = self.kernel_url if self.ramdisk_url: updates['/instance_info/ramdisk'] = self.ramdisk_url return updates

commit_message:
Avoid tox_install.sh for constraints support

We do not need tox_install.sh, pip can handle constraints itself
and install the project correctly. Thus update tox.ini and remove
the now obsolete tools/tox_install.sh file.

This follows https://review.openstack.org/#/c/508061 to remove
tools/tox_install.sh.

Change-Id: Ib9e007b9eeae5f2079dd682df0c7ef2294961f4f
(cherry picked from commit 3b5e6bc24fa1674cb7269ee21ba1f617df6b9357)
